>I have a simple question about arranging related tests inside a test =

>case:
>
>- Let`s say I have three tests that in some way depend on each o=
ther: 
>for example, a creation, a getter and a deletion method.
>These are=
 distinct functionalities, and thus deserve to be on 
>separate tests. The =
problem is: if one fails, the other two will run 
>anyway. But if the creat=
ion or getter methods fail, it doesn`t make 
>sense for me to test the dele=
tion method, as it depends on the 
>correctness of the other two. I know ca=
lling one test inside another 
>is not recommended. What should I do in thi=
s case? 

There are a few options, depending on the kind of tests you're ru=
nning.

1. Change your tests so that they can run independently. This is th=
e best overall approach.

2. Make your test fixture "self-repairing". Add l=
ogic to your test fixture so that it puts itself into the expected state ev=
en when a test fails. If you can do this, then you can probably do #1.

3. =
Place your tests into one, single test. You lose the ability to report on e=
ach test separately, but then I would argue that you really have one large =
test and not three smaller tests.

One question to ask: what are you trying=
 to test? If you are testing business logic that, as a side-effect, calls t=
hese methods you mention, then separate data access from business logic. If=
 you are testing your integration with a database, then you may be testing =
the database driver and not your code!

I hope this helps.
